segments.text: So after you worked in industry for a couple of years, Mr. Green?
So then were you free to do what you wanted?
And you were free to join the Communist Party overtly?
Were there any times, like in the 60s, where you felt the country was more receptive or warmer?
Well, it's a tremendous proof that it has to be a first world experience.
And, of course, that goes on back to tremendous...
Well, I think it inspired a lot of people, right?
And in so doing, being tolerant for minorities, the communists were more accepted?
Although, the McCartney period was something of a watershed for his life.
First, in regard to the country's ideology.
Second, in regard to the country's ideology.
In regard to the ideology, during the McCartney period, there were periods of oppression.
Or intolerance for any other ideology.
I used to live in Britain, and I lived in Canada, and I've been in the States six years now.
And I think part of it's got to do with lack of education.
We were... Well, in Britain and in Canada, we were...
They were a lot more open-minded about teaching other ideologies.
It wasn't the good versus the bad.
When I was in high school, at least...
And the government class we had were taught, American democracy, this is it.
Yeah, well, of course, that is another thing.
Now, we've had inflation, of course, because it's related to it.
In 1935, the average wage of something of a worker was something like $50 a week.
Now, if you multiply that 300 times, the average wage today would be $15,000 a week.
Do you know how ludicrous that is?
So you can see that the inflation of the military has far surpassed any.
Well, military has become a number one priority, unfortunately.
And also, we've reached a point now where so much has been targeted to the military, where
Now, also, when the war ended, we were the preeminent export nation in the world.
No one could compete with us.
If anyone mentioned that Arthur Beale, you always thought of Detroit.
But today, that's no longer the case.
What is happening today is we have a budget that just counts, mainly because of what we're spending on the military.
We also have a deficit of world trade, something like $125 billion a year short of foreign trade.
And the only two things we excel in now in export is first, agricultural growth of 70 billion.
all that impressed the one thing, the attainment of world supremacy.
At one point, after the war,
Do you think we're suffering because of the Reagan administration and, say, if things change in the next election, or is it just a current and it really doesn't matter who's in power?
In other words, the dominant sections of American capitalism
And the next group, combined with the military, who thought they had at that time, they had the deep weapon that could decide issues, namely the atom bomb.
I remember that when our trial began, the United States was the only country with the atom bomb.
They still talked about the Russian threat.
What has happened is a combination.
Yes, the Reagan administration has taken it to its extreme.
But it goes deeper than the Reagan administration.
So what's the outlook for the future?
No, I don't think it's pessimistic.
I believe that we are approaching a period when things are going to change.
First, Reagan has had a lot of luck in terms of the economy.
And I think the economy is going to have a downturn, and then things will get to face up to reality.
That the technological, scientific changes that are taking place in production are going to create a kind of problem.
Furthermore, that the country cannot completely recover the kind of deficit that it has in the federal budget.
Nor can it solve that problem by taking more from those who have less.
So I think that at this point, the great majority of the people want peace.
And I don't think too much happened in Geneva.
But at least there was a similar change between the two powers.
And it's interesting that the tremendous response that the Congress gave to the president, Democrats and Republicans alike,

Because generally, people feel that this offers a hope of some way of solving the crisis that we're getting into more deeply all the time, and the danger of a clear war that may destroy all life on Earth.
And I think that that is the significance of what happened there.
Although the fight is still ahead of us, we're turning that into some kind of meaningful change, putting the army race, burying it where it belongs to the barrier to being free.
Well, can I get your address?
I'd like to send you something.
Well, I'm graduating, but I'm quite certain that other students and my professor would be interested in having you come speak.
I was living, I spent some time with a friend who lives off West 22nd and Park this summer.
Yes, I do, by heart now.
Thank you very much, and the best of luck to you, and I hope your wife ends up getting better.
